Articles.Text: The neurons and other neural cells that SARS-CoV-2 is infecting, are shedding Spike and Nucleocapsid and levels are significantly higher in long COVID and even higher in long COVID with neuropsychiatric symptoms.
Convergent receptor binding domain evolution of BA.2.75 and BA.5.

13% of participants continued to shed SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the feces at 4 months after
				diagnosis & 4% shed at 7 months. GI symptoms are associated with fecal shedding of RNA.

Compared with healthy controls, the capillary density of Long COVID patients was
				decreased by 41%. Data strongly suggest that COVID leaves persistent capillary rarefication even 18 months after
				infection.
SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen in a majority of PASC patients up to 12 months post-diagnosis (n = 63), suggesting the presence of an active persistent SARS-CoV-2 viral reservoir.

Presence of residual virus within the appendix and breast tissue of 2 patients who exhibited LC symptoms, 175 to
				462 days upon positive diagnosis: positive staining for viral nucleocapsid protein (NP) in the appendix, and
				tumour-adjacent region of the breast, but not within the tumour via multiplex immunohistochemistry.
				Notably, with RNAscope, both positive-sense and negative-sense (replicative intermediate) viral RNA were
				detected.

Long COVID is very common.
				Systematic review and meta-analysis including 196 studies and 120,970 participants (mean age:
				52.3 years; 48.8% females) showed that long COVID may affect more than half of the patients, after a median of
				six months from the diagnosis.

In a large study with
				thousands of participants, vaccination did NOT reduce long COVID risks.

Small percentage of
				co-infections in SARS-CoV-2 positive patients who died with typical COVID-19 symptoms strongly suggests that the
				majority of SARS-CoV-2 infected patients died from and not with the virus.

Even in patients with
				mild COVID-19 who did not require supplemental oxygen or ventilatory support, sequelae were reported by 49.5% of
				them.

Almost all
				patients still showed some of the most debilitating symptoms (e.g., fatigue) after a year.

Persistent SARS-CoV-2
				infection in asymptomatic young adults.

According to a
				meta-analysis of 81 studies 32% of patients have fatigue at 12 weeks, 31% at 6+ months, 22% have cognitive
				impairment at 12 weeks, 21% at 6+ months.

Meta analysis shows that
				45% of post COVID patients have pulmonary fibrosis. Affected tend to be older and have suffered worse COVID
				course.

Endothelial cell
				infection and endotheliitis in COVID-19.

Antibody resistance of
				SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.1, BA.1.1, BA.2 and BA.3 Sub-lineages.
üíØ% of 177 infected health care workers developed auto antibodies.

No increase in auto
				antibodies after vaccination.

Immunological
				dysfunction persists for 8 months following initial mild-to-moderate SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Infection of primary human
				B and T cells by SARS-CoV-2 in vitro and in patients.

Older people have
				persistently aged T cells following covid.
Impaired Cytotoxic CD8 + T Cell Response in Elderly COVID-19 Patients.
üêÅ SARS-CoV-2 and its variants, but not Omicron, induces thymic atrophy and impaired T cell development.
üß´ ACE2-independent infection of T lymphocytes by SARS-CoV-2.

ORF1abA1061S potentiates autoreactive T cell responses via epitope
				mimicry: an explanation to hepatitis of unknown cause.

Liver injury,
				indicated by a high frequency of abnormal liver function tests, is a common clinical feature of COVID-19 in two
				independent cohorts of patients with COVID-19 requiring hospitalization.

Our data support the model in which SARS-CoV-2 reaches the brain, infects
				astrocytes, and consequently, leads to neuronal death or dysfunction. These deregulated processes could
				contribute to the structural and functional alterations seen in the brains of COVID-19 patients.

Mild respiratory infection with SARS-CoV-2 can result in persistent
				neuro-inflammatory changes and consequent dysregulation of
				neural cell types important for healthy cognitive function.

Long COVID is
				associated with extensive in vivo brain inflammation.
Cognitive deficits from long COVID are similar to aging the brain 20 years.
Covid smell loss linked to damage in brain.

The neurons and other neural cells that SARS-CoV-2 is infecting,
				are shedding Spike and Nucleocapsid and levels are significantly higher in
				long COVID and even higher in long COVID with neuropsychiatric symptoms.

SARS-CoV-2 is
				associated with changes in brain structure in UK Biobank study.

üíØ% of people
				with suspected and confirmed COVID-19 illness experienced cognitive deficits.
üêÅ Neuroinvasion and anosmia are independent phenomena upon infection with SARS-CoV-2 and its variants.

Persistent
				post-COVID-19 smell loss is associated with inflammatory infiltration and altered olfactory epithelial gene
				expression.

Loss of smell &
				taste intensified long after people had Covid.
Cross-reactive immunity against the SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant is low in pediatric patients with prior COVID-19 or MIS-C

Tallying the natural history of post-vaccine breakthrough infections (BTI) in 33,000 people with over 13 million controls gives a vaccination protection from long covid of around 15%, much less than many other studies (reporting around 50%).

A higher ICU admission rate was observed in reinfection compared to first infection. Complete recovery rate
				after reinfection stood at 97.9%.

Asymptomatic and
				mild COVID-19 significantly remodels the maternal-fetal interface.
				Single-cell RNA sequencing reveals immunological rewiring at the maternal-fetal interface following
				asymptomatic/mild SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Household transmission is
				high, and children are a major driver.

Wearing a mask is 1,000 times more important than wiping surfaces.
				The estimated probability of infection was about 1 per 100 exposures to SARS-CoV-2-laden aerosols through
				inhalation and as high as 1 per 100,000 exposures from contacting contaminated surfaces in simulated
				scenarios.
Vaccination and masking by teachers and students mitigates transmission in schools.

Aerosol particle
				escape from surgical masks due to imperfect sealing.

Overview of
				filtration efficiency through masks.

Comparison of
				FDA and NIOSH facemask and respirator filtration test methods. Particulate filtration efficiency (PFE),
				bacterial filtration efficiency (BFE) and viral filtration efficiency (VFE) are FDA methods. The NaCl aerosol
				test is an NIOSH method. NaCl method was significantly (p < 0.05) more strict.

A bearded man is a more
						dangerous carrier than a clean-shaven man...one working with infectious microorganisms should wash his
						beard.

Rapid initiation of twice-daily nasal saline irrigation reduces severity
				in high-risk COVID+ outpatients.

Of 272 (20%) healthcare workers who seroconverted, the presence of HLA-DRB1*13:02 was associated with a 6¬∑7-fold increased risk of case definition symptomatic COVID-19.
In terms of immune responsiveness, HLA-DRB1*15:02 was associated with lower nucleocapsid T-cell responses.

Larger gray matter volumes in neuropsychiatric long COVID.
Significantly enlarged gray matter volume in long COVID patients was present in several clusters when compared to controls.

Each SARS-CoV-2 reinfection causes more severe disease. Compared to people who did not get reinfection, those with reinfection had 2 fold increased risk of death, 3 fold increased risk of hospitalization, 3 fold increased risk of heart problems and 3 fold increased risk of blood clotting.
When compared to RT-qPCR, the sensitivity of Architect and Alinity SARS-CoV2 assays was 69.5% and 64.8%, respectively.
BQ.1.1 escapes Evusheld and bebtelovimab, making all clinically available antibody drugs ineffective. BQ.1.1 and BA.2.75.2 both displayed sufficient hACE2 binding capability.

SARS-CoV-2-specific T cell response magnitude is significantly greater in those who remain protected versus those who become infected (P<1e-4); relatively low magnitude T cell response results in a 43.2% risk of infection, whereas high magnitude reduces this risk to 5.4%.

Single-cell multiomics revealed the dynamics of antigen presentation, immune response and T cell activation in the COVID-19 positive and recovered individuals. Covid recovered are missing a subset of Naive T cells in general that are specific to other viruses.
No presence of the susceptible (HLA-DRB1*04) while protective allele for GCA (HLA-DRB1*15) allele was detected in two patients.
Defective antifungal immunity in patients with COVID-19
Evidence of viral presence in the lung up to 359 days after the acute phase of disease, including in patients with negative nasopharyngeal swab tests.
Some tests are more prone to seroreversion than others. Seroreversion, the opposite of seroconversion, is where antibody levels decrease in number over time.

National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease found that autopsies of people who died from COVID19 show that the virus spread throughout the body and remained in tissue for months. The study broadened scientists‚Äô perspectives on where SARS-CoV-2 could cause infection and persist, including the brain.

Tonsils and adenoids are important sites of SARS-CoV-2 infection in asymptomatic children. Flow cytometry revealed that CD123+ dendritic cells were the most frequently infected cell type (10.57%)  followed by CD14+ monocytes (6.32%), CD4+ T lymphocytes (1.75%), CD20+ B lymphocytes (1.67%), and in less extent CD8+ T lymphocytes cells (1.36%).

A cohort of #covid19 survivors (~ 58% fully vaccinated with mRNA post infection) show up for bariatric surgery. 1/3 had #SARSCOV2 proteins in their stomachs/gallbladders a median of 9+ months after covid19 irrespective of vax.

Markedly elevated levels of full-length spike protein, unbound by antibodies, were detected in the plasma of individuals with post-vaccine myocarditis, whereas no free spike was detected in asymptomatic vaccinated control subjects.
The role of NSP6 in the biogenesis of the SARS-CoV-2 replication organelle.
SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid exhibits significant homology with MS-associated proteins across both 9mer and 15mer peptide groups.

Presence of residual virus in the appendix, skin, and breast tissues of 2 patients who exhibited Long COVID symptoms 163 and 426 days after symptom onset. With multiplex immunohistochemistry, viral nucleocapsid protein was detected in all three tissues. The nucleocapsid protein was further observed to co-localize with macrophage marker CD68, suggesting that immune cells were direct targets of SARS-CoV-2. Additionally, using RNAscope, the presence of viral RNA was also detected
Why does viral RNA sometimes persist after recovery from acute infections?

There was a significant difference in the allele frequency of HLA-DRB1*04:01 in the severe patient compared to the asymptomatic staff group (5.1% vs. 16.7%, P = .003 after adjustment for age and sex). There was a significantly lower frequency of the haplotype DQA1*01:01-DQB1*05:01-DRB1*01:01 in the asymptomatic group compared to the background population (P = .007).
Significant alteration of reproductive function at the molecular level. Several dysregulated proteins identified.
Beyond an association, as established in many previous reports, evidence from Mendelian randomization that Covid can cause atrophy in specific brain regions.

SARS-CoV-2-immunoreactive neurons were detected in the dorsal medulla and in the substantia nigra of five COVID-19 subjects. Viral RNA was also detected by real-time RT-PCR. The results of this study support the neuroinvasive potential of SARS-CoV-2.

COVID-19 patients had reduced thymic function, which was inversely associated with the severity of the disease. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) was expressed by thymic epithelium, and in particular by medullary thymic epithelial cells (TEC). SARS-CoV-2 can target TECs and downregulate critical genes and pathways associated with epithelial cell adhesion and survival.
Persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection in patients seemingly recovered from COVID-19.
How SARS-CoV-2 battles our immune system
Only 9% of people with persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection reported having Long COVID

Muscle biopsy in-depth assessment in people with Long Covid with exercise symptoms compared with 2 control groups shows microvascular abnormalities with reduced capillaries, immune cell dysregulation, distinct gene expression signature.

Long COVID manifests with T cell dysregulation, inflammation, and an uncoordinated adaptive immune response to SARS-CoV-2. Individuals with LC harbored increased frequencies of CD4+ T cells poised to migrate to inflamed tissues, and exhausted SARS-CoV-2-specific CD8+ T cells. They also harbored significantly higher levels of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies, and in contrast to non-LC individuals, exhibited a mis-coordination between their SARS-CoV-2-specific T and B cell responses.

üêÅSpike protein infusion into mouse brain induces late cognitive dysfunction. Spike protein induces late hippocampal microgliosis and synapse loss. Blockage of TLR4 renders mice resistant to Spike-induced cognitive dysfunction. TLR4-2604G>A GG genotype (rs10759931) was related to poor cognitive outcomes in COVID-19 patients.
Class switch toward non-inflammatory, spike-specific IgG4 antibodies after repeated SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.
T cell apoptosis characterizes severe Covid-19 disease.
Single-cell atlas reveals shared and distinct immune responses and metabolism during SARS-CoV-2 and HIV-1 infections.
T-Cell Hyperactivation and Paralysis in Severe COVID-19 Infection Revealed by Single-Cell Analysis
Post-COVID syndrome is associated with capillary alterations, macrophage infiltration and distinct transcriptomic signatures in skeletal muscles.
To varying degrees, viral RNA is present in extrapulmonary tissues from all subjects. The majority of the 180 viral variants identified within subjects are unique to individual tissue samples.

Detailed evaluation of the lung immune compartment revealed that dysregulated respiratory CD8+ T cell responses were associated with the impaired lung function after acute COVID-19. Single-cell transcriptomic analysis identified the potential pathogenic subsets of respiratory CD8+ T cells contributing to persistent tissue conditions after COVID-19.
Evidence of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein on retrieved thrombi from COVID-19 patients.
Desk shields between students in schools are the one measure that is associated with a higher risk of developing COVID symptoms.
Circulating spike protein in the blood of long haulers, but not controls, 12 months post diagnosis.

Using conventional immunohistochemistry, we detected SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein in the colon, appendix, ileum, haemorrhoid, liver, gallbladder and lymph nodes from 5 patients who recovered from COVID-19, 9-180 days after testing negative for SARS-CoV-2.
In pregnant women who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, normalised fetal lung volume was significantly reduced compared with age-adjusted reference values.

Of the 109 patients, 29 (27%) experienced reactivation, and seven (24%) of these were symptomatic. The mean period for the real-time PCR tests for SARS-CoV-2 from negative to positive results was 17 days. Compared with patients without reactivation, those with reactivation were significantly younger and more likely to have a lymphocyte count of <1500/ŒºL (odds ratio [OR]: 0.34, 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.12‚Äì0.94) and two or fewer symptoms (OR: 0.20, 95% CI: 0.07‚Äì0.55) during the initial episode.
Electrostatic interactions are a major contributing factor for increased Omicron transmissibility relative to other variants.
One year after infection, over 25% of people had lung diffusion issues.

Severe COVID-19 is marked by activated, highly cytotoxic CD16+ T cells. Immune-complex-mediated degranulation of CD16+ T cells causes endothelial cell injury. C3a-rich environment in severe COVID-19 promotes differentiation of CD16+ T cells. Activated CD16+ T cells and complement proteins are associated with fatal outcome

Deaths reported within 28 days of testing positive were 61% (95% confidence interval: 56% to 65%) lower in suspected COVID-19 reinfection than primary infection cases. In the unvaccinated cohort, reinfections were associated with 49% (37% to 58%) lower odds of hospital admission in cases aged 50 to 65 years in the population not identified at risk of complication for COVID-19, and 34% (17% to 48%) in those at risk.
SARS-CoV-2 invades cognitive centers of the brain and induces Alzheimer‚Äôs-like neuropathology.

Omicron variant of SARS-CoV-2 exhibits an increased resilience to the antiviral type I interferon response. IFN induction by Omicron is low and comparable to the wt, whereas Delta showed an increased IFN induction. However, Omicron exceeded both the wt and the Delta strain with respect to the ability to withstand the antiviral state imposed by IFN-alpha.

A low count of CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes is a hallmark laboratory finding in the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Using flow cytometry, significantly higher CD95 (Fas) and PD-1 expression on both CD4+ T and CD8+ T cells were observed in 42 COVID-19 patients when compared to controls. Higher CD95 expression in CD4+ cells correlated with lower CD4+ counts. A higher expression of CD95 in CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes correlated with a lower percentage of naive events. This suggests a shift to antigen-activated T cells, expressing molecules increasing their propensity to apoptosis and exhaustion during COVID-19 infection.

Not only are COVID-19 cases who got 2 vaccine doses reporting much less Long COVID symptoms than unvaccinated - they're reporting no more than uninfected people - suggesting vaccination brings these symptoms back to baseline.
Significant proportion of severe COVID19 patients actually developed auto-antibodies against interferon type I.
80% of peripheral T cells die during SARS Cov 2 infection, with proliferation of 20% of the CD8 T cell pool.
Significant posterior ocular structural & vascular alterations in patients with severe COVID infections.
White Cells (monocytes) switch gene expression from an established innate immune profile to a pro-clotting signature in COVID.
üêÅCovid infects the central nervous system in mouse models. Inflammation was consistently observed, with death of endothelial, microglial and immune cells but without their apparent infection.

Alterations in brain functioning, especially in regions associated with cognition, can result from infection with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and are predicted to result in various psychiatric diseases.
